headline.main: Some Extra Heft May Be Helpful, New Study Says

docs.abstract: Researchers at National Cancer Institute and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention find that people who are overweight but not obese have lower risk of death than those of normal weight and that being very thin causes slight increase in risk of death, even if thinness is longstanding and not related to disease; say increased risk of death from obesity is for most part in the extremely obese, group constituting only 8 percent of Americans; findings are unexpected and are met with full gamut of responses from experts; some see study as reality check on what they consider nation's near-hysteria over fat; others voice skepticism; drawing (M)

keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: People who are overweight but not obese have a lower risk of death than those of normal weight, federal researchers are reporting today. The researchers -- statisticians and epidemiologists from the National Cancer Institute and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention -- also found that increased risk of death from obesity was seen for the most part in the extremely obese, a group constituting only 8 percent of Americans.
docs.snippet: People who are overweight but not obese have a lower risk of death than those of normal weight, federal researchers said.

keywords.value: EVIDENCE OF HARM. MERCURY IN VACCINES AND THE AUTISM EPIDEMIC: A MEDICAL CONTROVERSY (BOOK)
keywords.name: creative_works

docs.lead_paragraph: EVIDENCE OF HARM Mercury in Vaccines and the Autism Epidemic: A Medical Controversy. By David Kirby. 460 pp. St. Martin's Press. $26.95.
docs.snippet: The journalist David Kirby recounts the battle between the medical establishment and parents.

headline.main: The Body Heretic: It Scorns Our Efforts

docs.lead_paragraph: THE promises are everywhere. Sure, you smoked. But you can erase all those years of abusing your lungs if you just throw away the cigarettes. Eating a lot of junk food? Change your diet, lose even 5 or 10 pounds and rid yourself of those extra risks of heart disease and diabetes. Stay out of the sun -- who cares if you spent your youth in a state of bronzed bliss? If you protect yourself now, skin cancer will never get you. Maybe it should be no surprise that America's popular and commercial cultures promote the idea of an inexhaustible capacity for self-rejuvenation and self-repair. After all, if America as an idea has meant anything, it has meant just that -- the possibility of continual transformation -- becoming wealthier, more spiritual, more beautiful, happier and feeling younger.
docs.snippet: There are real limits to what can be done to reverse the damage caused by a lifetime of unhealthy living.
